description.text: Der Zerhacker.

I needed to cut a couple of thousand SMD parts.
So i built a robot :)

The SPROCKET is available here:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/J7000794-sam-sung-CP45-12mm-smt-feeder-sprocket-spring/32660840478.html

The IR sensor i used is here:
http://www.electrodragon.com/product/tcrt5000-infrared-reflective-proximity-sensor/

The arduino source is in zerhacker.zip (also here)

I have no schematics online as i built this machine from parts i had laying around on perfboard.
This is not ment to be super easy to build yourself.
It is not well documented and I will not do it as i have not much spare time.

If you build a machine based on / inspired by this files, please be so kind and document your work online so others can benefit from it.

:*
-flo

author: aza_4

title: Belt clip camera holster for Canon Powershot

description.text:
Holds my point and shoot camera on my belt. Yes. I'm that guy - at work at least.

The process of using a smartphone for documenting items for my home inspections is too slow. I carry a point and shoot with good optical zoom and time and date stamp. Projects like making this holster to carry my camera securely on my hip was my main reason I wanted to get a 3D printer. It may not be a work of art but it works like a charm.

I have plenty of old clips around so I didnt need to print the clip part. This is simply the body to hold a small Canon Powershot can't remember the model the text is worn off on the camera.

I roughly modeled my point and shoot camera in Vectorworks then modeled the holster. I have numerous old iPhone belt clips around the house so I adapted the holder to accept the spring, pin and clip part from commercially bought phone holsters

print_settings.Notes:: The screw holes are modelled as ø3mm for the mating hole, and 3.75mm for the larger clearance hole. This is to allow for some reduction in hole diameters due to printing tolerances.

title: Arrow Roller Blind Cord Connectors or Ends
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These roller blind ends can be used to either terminate the ends of a cut or broken roller blind chain, or to join a cord together again.

Simply pick which style of arrow you want, then print two of it (you need to print two halves per arrow). Then join the two halves together using a couple of ø3mm x 7.5mm screws.

This connector is designed for roller blinds consisting of ø4.5mm beads, spaced at ~12.15mm intervals along ø1.6mm cord.

The square holes for the beads are 5mm cubes, and cord hole through the centre is 2.5mm wide x 2mm deep.

I designed the arrows to screw together, rather than gluing or clipping together, to make them easily removable and very strong. I picked the ø3mm screws, as I have a LOT of them, as a result of disassembling various electrical items (printers, radios, microwaves, etc), which tend to use a lot of this type of screw.

If simply terminating the cords, rather than joining a cord together again, the arrows can be used to show which direction the blinds will go if you pull on that end of the cord. the arrows can be installed pointing either direction, and can be installed at the end of the cord or part way along. They're versatile!

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

The screw holes are modelled as ø3mm for the mating hole, and 3.75mm for the larger clearance hole. This is to allow for some reduction in hole diameters due to printing tolerances.

For Assembly

2 of ø3mmx7.5mm long screws for assembly (per arrow)
(you'll end up with a heap of these screws if you disassemble old printers or electronics)

Bolt Gun G36 Kit

This Kit is designed to fit on airsoft G36 replica's. In this case an SRC GEN 3 was used. It is designed to be fully removalable for maintanance. Its internal design ensures it fits snug and secure on the airsoft replica.

*Note if you have a G36 of another brand compatiblity cant not be promised and some small modification may be required. A TM compatible magwell has been provided as an optional part if required.

Recommended Equipment:

Glue (2 part epoxy was used)
Various grades of sandpaper (from 150 down to 3000, though this is optional and use your own discretion)
Allen keys (to affix the bolts)
(Bolts/screws are qty=2 (M4x25mm), qty=6 (M4X8mm), qty=2 (M4x12mm), qty=1 (M6X45mm) and you will need nuts for those 10x m4 and 1x M6
Bar Clamps (or other equipment to hold parts while glue sets)
Needle files (for finishing and adjusting fit)

Parts List:

FPlate - Front Plate
FrontSideL - Front Side Left
FrontSideR - Front Side Right
FGrip - Front Grip
MidSideL - Middle Side Left
MidSideR - Middle Side Right
MidGrip - Middle Grip
RearSideL - Rear Side Left
RearSideR - Rear Side Right

RailA1 - Front end of railsection
RailB1 - 2nd part of rail section
RailC1 - 3rd part of rail section
RailD1 - 4th part of rail section

Connector1 - First part of the upper rail section
Connector2 - 2nd part of upper rail section
Connector3 - 3rd part of upper rail section
Connector4 - 4th part of upper rail section

Grips - Grips for front end (need 4 of these)

Muz - Muzzle
MuzRing - Muzzle ring

FNub - Front Nubbin

Eagle - Eagle Emblem

FSight - Front sight
Rsight - Rear Sight

ChargeH - Fake Charging Nubbin

Optional Parts:

TMMagTop - TM compatible Magwell Top
TMMagBot - TM compatible Magwell Bottom

Step 1: Front End

Assemble these parts to create Front End section 1 and glue (See image https://thingiverse-production-new.s3.amazonaws.com/renders/8f/df/9c/6d/3b/4175a38a32bbdcffdfbd120568a81e82_preview_featured.jpg)
FPlate - Front Plate
FrontSideL - Front Side Left
FrontSideR - Front Side Right
FGrip - Front Grip

Assemble these parts to create Front End section 2 and glue (See image https://thingiverse-production-new.s3.amazonaws.com/renders/7a/c8/e2/72/7f/77ae8c373087666dfa784e0bb3844616_preview_featured.jpg)
MidSideL - Middle Side Left
MidSideR - Middle Side Right
MidGrip - Middle Grip
RearSideL - Rear Side Left
RearSideR - Rear Side Right
*Note the part "ChargeH" needs to be fitted to the part "RearSideR"

Assemble both Sections and glue (See image "Front End")

Step 2: Top Rail

Assemble these parts to create Top Rail Section 1 and glue them together into 1 single piece.
Connect1
Connect2
Connect3
Connect4
Ensure they are orientated correctly!

Assemble the parts to create Top Rail Section 2 and only glue the nuts into each segment. The segments must remain seperate!
RailA1
RailB1
RailC1
RailD1

Step 3: Magwell

Assemble the parts to create the magwell and glue
MagL - Left hand side of magwell
MagR - Right hand side of magwell
MagLA - Left hand side magwell part2
MagRA - Ritght hand side magwell part2
*MagTop - Top section to interface with SRC hop unit

*Exchange for the two parts below to chnage it from SRC compatible to TM compatible
TMMagTop - Top section to interface with TM Style hop unit
TMMagBot - Bottom section to interface with TM Style hop unit
(some filing may be required to get it to feed BB's correctly and allow the nozzle to pass)

Step 4: Muzzle

Fit part: MuzRing into back of the frontplate, this will allow part: Muz to fit onto it

Step 5: Front Sight

The part: FSight allows two nuts to run inside of it and is the screwed on from underneath so that it attaches to part: RailA1
(see images for clarification)

Step 6: Rear Sight

The part: RSight other than providing a rear sight helps to hold the front end flush to the G36 replica.
Special Notes:

Step 7: Grips

The part: Grips can be fitted at your discretion and in any number (i used 4 evenly spaced.

Step 8: Eagle

The part: Eagle can be fitted at your discretion.

NOTES

Please refer to images prior to gluing. Always double check parts. Some sanding/adjustment may be required.
Have fun
Remixes should be great fun if you can improve this model :)

title: ESS Goggles 30x10mm Fan and 9V Battery Housing

description.text:
A mount for a 30x10mm fan to vent my ESS goggles. The fan I had lying around was 12v, so I figured a 9v battery would be sufficient. Note that this is for the ESS Tactical SC Thermal goggles, an older model that has been out of production for quite some time, so this may or may not fit on the newer designs. Please leave a comment with the model you have if you make one and it does or does not fit.

This is still a work in progress. I plan to add strain relief and/or holders/clips for the wires, but that will come later, if at all.

The two barbed tabs fit into the top of the mask with some of the foam removed, and on either side there are holes to zip tie it in place to the mask through some of the aligned ventilation holes. The two halves of the fan housing may be held together in the front with zip ties or screws. I may make a version with a recess for nylock nuts later on.

For the version with the switch, I am using a rocker switch that I picked up from Microcenter, part 54-870 from NTE.

Supports are only required for the battery holder in the middle section where the strap is fed in. Print the battery holder with the opening for the battery facing up.

Printed in nylon.

As I used nylon for this, I dyed it with dark brown rit dye as per the dying instructions I found here. I ended up making too strong a solution and/or soaking for too long, but I am still happy with the outcome.

description.text:
This is a 100mm x 100mm VESA monitor bracket for use with HumanScale monitor arms. This bracket is to be mounted on the back of a computer monitor, then it slides into the mount on a HumanScale monitor arm.

This bracket has been designed in two parts to ease printability as well as increase strength. The diamond shaped boss on the "Monitor Bracket.stl" is designed to be press fit into the diamond shaped hole on the "MonitorNub.stl" creating a mechanical bond between the two parts which is reinforced by the 4x M3x16mm socket cap head screws. Do not over tighten the screws connecting the bracket to the monitor! Getting them "Snug" is all that is necessary. Over tightening could cause the layers to delaminate and the part to fail.
I use M4 x 14 x .7 pitch screws to mount the bracket to the back of the monitor.

Do not use this bracket unless you have installed the 4x M3x16mm socket cap head screws these screws are a critical component in the design and strength of this part.

I have mounted 6 monitors using these brackets with zero failures so far. Use good judgment, some monitors are much heavier than others and may not be a good choice for use with this mount.

By downloading and printing this part you accept full responsibility for any damages that may result from the use of this part. I cannot be held liable for damages that may result from the proper or improper use of this part.

Printer:

OpenBeam Kossel Pro

Doesn't Matter

No

.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Set perimeters and top and bottom layers to a minimum of 4 for good strength, However, the more the better. I've printed all of mine in PLA but other materials like PET will likely yield a stronger part.

Due to variances in machines the "MonitorNub" may require some sanding or edge trimming with a razor blade to get it to fit smoothly into the mount. I recommend test fitting the nub before assembling it onto the "Monitor Bracket".

description.text:
this is my first brushless gimbal for a mobius camera.
the motors and the controller are from rctimer:
  • 2804-100T brushless gimbal motor
  • 2-axis brushless gimbal controller & imu v1.0
    additional parts are:
  • anti-vibration rubber balls from rctimer
  • ball bearing 8x4x3 mm
  • bolt m4 x 10 mm
  • nut m4
    the controller software is from here:
    http://sourceforge.net/projects/brushless-gimbal-brugi/
    here are a few movies with the gimbal in action.
    http://youtu.be/fo5YV5kvk_Q
    http://youtu.be/WvwDGBNRNxs
    http://youtu.be/uUQwaLmqgO4
    http://youtu.be/MbdtZ-Mk_3E
    update:
  • arm2_final_v2 is an updated version, that adds a bit more space for the sensor module unter the camera.
  • arm1_final_v2 is an updated version, with less imbalance on the roll axis, in case the camera is attached to the frame without additional weight from alpha gel pads.
  • arm3_final_v2 added hole for zip tie (idea by marhar).

the design is pretty simple, just print the three arms, insert the ball bearing, attach the motors and the motion sensing unit.
upload the software, choose the correct motor number ant their rotation direction, then adjust the pid settings...
finding the correct pid settings caused a bit of a headache.
the creo elements express (free 3d cad) file of the entire assembly can also be downloaded in case someone wants to modify the design.

description.text:
This part was designed to decrease heatbed vibrations by the means of increasing the overall torsion strenght of the bed holder. The z-axis space will not be decreased, since it just wraps around the bearings.
The part is placed over the z-axis bearings and screwed in place with the bearing screws. The z-axis space will not be decreased, since it just wraps around the bearings. The parts are interconnected via m5 srew. At bearing side you can insert m5 scres and tighten them against the z axis bearing. Also m5 screws and nuts are inserted vertically in the corresponding holes. To increase tension to the headbed holder you can A) use the screws to adjust tightness B) attach some layers of duct tape between heatbed holder and stiffeners.

Also make sure to tighten the headbed hight adjustment srews nearly all the way and just leave little space for adjusting, since this already decreases heatbed oszillations significant.

The screwholes have been designed a little bit to tight, so you can bore them in post processing.

Unfortunately after testing, I found this didnt decreases heatbed oszillations as expected. Did a static test, where a random heavy object (1382g) has been blaced on the heatbed and measured the deflection without (47.08mm - 45.99mm = 1.09mm) and with headbed stiffeners attached (48.49mm - 47.53mm = 0.96mm).

However heatbed seems realy rigid right now. Now it seems, that z coupler and z axis motor holder are some sources of heatbed flex.

title: Moon bump mapped (like THE BEST one on Thingiverse if I do say so myself)

description.text:
I searched a zillion sites for a bump mapped moon without distortion. The couple on thingiverse are either pretty low-res, or have significant distortions about the pole. The heck with it, I thought, off to learn UV mapping in blender. I downloaded NASA high res topos of the moon and finally figured out after hours and hours how to make a moon (or any planet really) without significant distortion at the poles. Yes, uv wrapping what eventually ends up a sphere does distort a bit at the poles and it really can not be helped. BUT, once printed, you can not see the ever so slight pinch in the last 1% of the model (well, maybe Neil deGrasse Tyson could, and if you're on here - just zip the lip smart guy). No huge rifts like the other guys model. No low res mess up poles either.

EDIT: Added compressed file that contains original and shell only version. With the shell only you can bisect and print vase mode or use infill and print solid. Original one had inner wall so you had to monkey with it for a solid model

title: Phantom 3 Full Coverage Prop Guard - Snap On

description.text:
Version 2: I added 10mm to the height of the uprights to give a bit more clearance for the props. If you do not build the assembly flat, the spanners that go between the guards could hit a propeller.

I needed a propeller guard to give me full protection of the blades while operating near
objects and one that I could print with my FlashForge 3D printer. The design is a snap
on type and is easily installed and removed. This is designed to fit on most 3D-Printing
beds that are at least 190mm X 140mm. The spanners between the guards are not
necessary. They can easily be assembled with super glue or plastic solvent.

Each print makes one guard and one spanner. I like to print them in bright colors so I can
easily distinguish the front of the drone.

title: Laser Honeycomb Grill Solid Material Standoff

description.text: If you purchase a laser cutter/engraver from ebay, aliexpress, etc... they often come with a honeycomb platform. Cutting with your material direclty on this platform can result in flashback or flares and burnt spots on the bottom. They also don't really provide adequate registration for repeatability. These pins with corner guides can hold most firm materials up off the grill and also give you a set location to place blanks if you are repeating the same object multiple times. They are designed to be adjustable within the spacing of most honeycomb grids.

author: loyano

title: E3D V6 Part Cooling Duct for Tronxy P802

description.text:
This is a new and improved cooling duct design for my E3D V6 mount design https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2536764 that I made for my Tronxy P802E. This duct is much smaller than my crazy wide duct I posted initially. It is half the size and even works a bit better.

My goals with this were:

  • To make a duct that was fairly compact. (at least as small a most ducts out there)
  • Cool at least as well as my previous duct which did a pretty good job.
  • Provide relatively even cooling on all sides of a print.
  • Be fairly easy to print.
  • Allow visibility to the nozzle.

I feel I was successful on all counts. It cools great at all angles around prints. It does cool a bit better on the front facing side so keep that in mind if you have any super extreme overhang angles.

See my overhang test flower. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2561815
It is one thing that I used to evaluate the cooling of extreme overhangs.

Keep posted as I expect I will continue to keep improving it.

Printer:

Tronxy P802E

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Notes:

You should use ABS. You will need to rotate the model so it sits flat of course.
I suggest using .2mm layers. You may need light part cooling to print the bridging areas best.

I included some supports at the air exhaust slots that you will need to remove. I found that using an exacto knife to slowly cut at the tips of the supports in a prying action worked best. I would stick the knife between supports and work it back and forth. I'd advise you to not just try and break the supports off as it could take some of the part with it.

I applied aluminum tape to areas directly next to the heat block. This probably isn't necessary with ABS, but I figured it wouldn't hurt.

If the duct fits a little too loose in your blower then apply a bit of high quality duct tape (or something like that) to the front and/or back surfaces that insert into the fan. Doing that allows mine to fit very securely while still being easy to take on and off.

description.text:
Shock mount for the Zoom H1 Audio Recorder.

I was looking for a way to mount my Zoom H1 recorder to my mic stand. There a few other mounts on the site, but I wanted something that looked more like a piece of regular studio equipment and provided a little more security for the H1.

The mount I designed uses normal rubber bands for suspension, and the H1 is secured in the mount by a camera 1/4-20 thumbscrew. This assures that the recorder can be oriented in whatever position you want without fear of it sliding out of the mount. The H1 can be removed from the mount while keeping the inner mount attached to outer ring. It also allows access to the power/hold switch, the audio settings switches and recording stop/start button. I gave it tunnels on both sides to avoid rubbing on the buttons that are on the sides of the H1.

The mount doesn't give access to the side buttons, but I don't normally use those while I'm recording. I may redesign the mount in the future to add external buttons that can operate the H1's buttons.

You can orient the H1 in any direction you'd like by rotating the inner ring during assembly.

Both pieces of the mount are designed to be printed without support. However, depending on your printer, you may need support inside the holes.

I'm using the InnerGear Microphone Stand, Model: MU01

The mount is meant to replace the MIC holder that comes with the Mic stand. It uses the original screw.

The rubber bands can be secure with a toothpick or similar rod. I'm using short pieces of filament.

Car glovebox hinges are broken on the old commodore, along with the little catches that prevent the glovebox from opening too far. The original catch is made from rubber so the glovebox has a nice feel when it opens but ABS will do!

I designed both parts in Fusion 360 and have attached the f3d files in case you want to improve or modify the design.

Updated:
I didn't notice the previous owner had tried to use doublesided mounting tape to fix the glovebox and so I had modelled the clip to include the thickness of the steel+tape. (I had a few drinks in me last night while I had the vernier callipers under the dash haha)

I've since removed the mounting tape and remodelled the clip to suit just the steel as well as thickening the upper brace and top of the clip as well as making the top circular so the filament flows smoothly with no sharp rectangular angles which hopefully makes it stronger.

They are fitted now and working well!

title: Improved Endcap for Dyson DC 44 Animal

description.text:
Oh, my lovely wife, I taught her how to clean the brush bar of our DC 44 Animal as we needed to clean it more and more often as we just got two long-haired dogs. However, she took a pair of scissors to the "coin screw" slot that you're supposed to use and basically ruined it. So I had to design a new part.

I realised with the amount that this dang part it silly that I need to keep finding a coin to open the brush bar. So, I took the opportunity to improve the design slightly and put a lever to hand open the part.

Problem solved!

I put very little tolerance on the brass bushing part in the end cap, but what works well (as it is a slightly round shape) is heat-setting the brass part in the end. when setting it turn it a bit and it will allow the round part to still rotate slightly.

Printer:

ME3d Me2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2um

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Printed with Polymaker Polylite at a high temp (max temp suggested) to make sure that the layer adhesion was good. I also printed 4 walls and 4 top/bottom layers for extra strength.

title: USB Thumb Drive and OTG Adapter Case

description.text:
This is my first completed design.

I had a few problems. Shipping USB thumb drives with documents ran into a snag when one of the drives in a bubble mailer was damaged in transit. Add to that, sometimes an OTG adapter was needed so the client could read the files from their phone.

So, two problems with one solution: an easy-to-print case that could not only hold 2 thumb drives but also slot an OTG adapter that would fit snug and not come out but be easy for a human to remove. And it should survive the rigors of courier transport.

Hopefully someone else may find this of use. It is a much stronger alternative to simply trusting a bubble mailer to do the job.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

20% infill makes for some sturdy walls. If you're concerned and need more support, 30% will make this super strong.

Printed with PLA.

Cover Fitting

The cover is design to sit flush with the rest of the case and snug so it doesn't come off during transit. This may not be what you want, however. I recommend widening the cover by 0.25mm on the X- and Y-axes to make the fit looser if this is an issue.

This an oil pump I designed to help service oils where the entry point is tight or elevated. I am an aircraft mechanic so I would use this to service starters or the various motor gearboxes. But it can be used in a wide variety of applications.

It is designed to sit on top of a 1 qt metal oil can. It requires a 6v peristaltic pump, 4 AA battery housing (links below), and a switch. Plus associated tubing, wires etc.

I sold my printer before I got to print the final design. I know the specs are good, and everything fits, but I don't know if it ACTUALLY works.

description.text:
Note 1: You will need two of the "pin1.stl" because the knife needs two pins to hold the grips to the "tang." The grips are simply mirrors of each other.

Note 2: Files have been updated to be aligned correctly on a bed. You may still need to rotate bladewithtang.stl to fit on your print area, but I found printing it edge-up makes cleanup a lot easier.

I wanted to make a "realistic" tanto point-style knife* and try printing in PLA and then softening the blade with acetone to make it a safe trainer or prop for a costume. Currently printing and will report back once I've tried soaking in acetone to soften the blade.

Update 2/27/18: So I put the blade part in an acetone vapor bath at ~room temperature for 5 hours. The PLA temporarily softened to about a hardish rubber (like an eraser). However, byt the next day, most of the softness had disappeared. The acetone also did not melt the PLA like it would with ABS (which is good). The blade is also not brittle, though it does still feel hard. BTW, I'm using Hatchbox PLA. I'm not sure if this effect happens with other types of PLA since it might be due to impurities in the specific filament itself.

*I made this in the style of BF3 and BF4's ACB-90 knife (aka the boxcutter), so that's why the cutting edges are the way they are. It's kind of like a backwards tanto.

comments.text: I found out in the meantime that you have to take certain precautions when slicing objects in Simplify3D that contain intersecting "outside" surfaces on the inside. Specifically you need to choose an option from the slicer Menu called "Mesh->Separate connected surfaces". That way, the slicer separates the object into all the 430+ geometric elements (mostly cubes, naturally) it was made of originally. After that, the object slices nicely, without any surface problems.

description.text:
A quick an easy upgrade for the Wombot Exllis to upgrade to a E3d style hot-end using bowden feed. Inspired by the hypercube

Remove and ditch the mark 8 extruder.

Remove the stepper motor and fit to stepper mount, fit to top rail top rail

Using 2 of the original mounting screws with the spaces that are in the stepper mount stl re install the screws holding the motor together in the top two rear holes

Fit a mark 10 extruder to the stepper motor.

Put a 30mm m3 screw in the rear bottom hole of the stepper motor that is now missing a screw.

On the rear of the the hot end mount there are 2 hex holes, insert m3 by 15mm hex standoffs and then plug holes with the 2 hex plugs in the stl.

fit the hotend mount onto the original carriage where the stepper motor was mounted using m3 by 15mm screws

install the new hot end and clamp up using m3 by 32 screws

Slide the fan duct into place and fix with #4 by 9mm self tappers

Fit the blower fan using a m3 by 32 screw

Adjust the height of the bltouch as required

And it should be good to go.

I got all my screws from Jaycar.

design files are included

40mm fan adaptor was from the link below
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2572641

This is a hexapod robot I designed and built. First, I want to say that this was my original work. The inspiration for the arduino mega mount came from the OpenSCAD mounting library by kellyegan, but it is not the same file copied. This robot uses 18 servos and uses my custom screw free servo mount. If you want the files for everything message me. I am asking for a donation. It can be $0.01. Anything helps, I'm a college student. Also, with the donations I will put together instructions to make a control board and code for the robot.

My patreon: https://www.patreon.com/danielkgoto
My paypal: paypal.me/DanielGoto

title: Thick Lacquering for PLA Models
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Fill the remaining grooves on the surface of the PLA models and build a thick coat to further protect it.
This way is suitable for models with simple shapes, but it is not suitable for models with complex shapes.

⚠Cautions

  • Ventilate the room during painting/drying/vaporing
  • Do not place the painted PLA models near the fire

🛒Requirements

🎨For Lacquering

  • 1 x Sanding sealer
    • Choose a sanding sealer containing nitrocellulose as a substrate
    • Choose a sanding sealer with high ratio of ethyl acetate or butyl acetate as solvent
    • Use as a top coat of third layer
      • If you are concerned about patterns appearing on the painted surface, use the nail top coat
      • In case of emphasizing safety, it is good to use paint not containing nitrocellulose as top coat (However, smoothing with acetone vapor becomes impossible)
    • Mix with starch or ink respectively to use for under/middle coat of second/third layer
    • When mixing, slowly rotate the container
      • Bubbles appear when using ice cream sticks
  • 1 x Starch (corn or potato etc...)
    • Mix with the sanding sealer and use it for the sealing of the first layer
    • Use ice cream sticks when mixing
      • When starch is mixed with sealer, bubbles rarely appear
  • * x Refill inks for permanent marker
    • Choose your favorite ink color
    • Mix with the sanding sealer and use it for the painting of the second layer
    • When mixing, slowly rotate the container
      • Bubbles appear when using ice cream sticks
  • * x Jam jars
    • Use as a container for paint mixed with sanding sealer and starch/ink
  • * x Ice cream sticks
    • Use for mixing the paint of first layer
    • Use to substitute for brush
  • * x Wet sandpapers (400-1000 grit)
    • Use to sanding each layers

🚿For Acetone Vaporing

  • 1 x Acetone
    • Exposure to acetone vapor for 5 minutes will smooth the coated surface
  • 1 x Big jar
    • I used a PET jar and a polypropylene lid, but it good worked without dissolving in acetone
    • Use to upside down
  • 1 x Paper towel
    • Drop acetone on a paper towel and vaporize it
  • 1 x Aluminum foil
    • Stick to the inside of the big jar lid and place the PLA model on it
  • 1 x PVAc glue
    • Use to stick the paper towel inside the big jar
    • Use to stick the aluminum foil to the inside of the big jar lid

🔗Reference Links

  • Lacquering related links
    • use of sanding sealer and primer
    • RCU Forums - Finishing with dope and talcum powder
  • Acetone vaporing related links
    • Cold acetone vapor polishing
    • 7 Steps to shiny porcelain finish on 3D printed ABS parts with acetone
  • 3D models used for slideshow images
    • Sweetheart Flowers by MakerBot
    • Toothbrush Holder for Tray (V2)
    • M18x2.5 Nut Spinner
    • diep.io Tank Set Tier 3

comments.text:
So, what brand(s) have you used/recommend? Looking at:
-Minwax Lacquer Sanding Sealer
-Mylands Cellulose Sanding Sealer
-Deft Lacquer Sanding Sealer
comments.author: esurplusplus

comments.text:
The amount of solvent is more important than brand.
Please look at the SDS/MSDS of the products you mentioned.
https://www.minwax.com/document/SDS/en/US/027426154001
http://www.highlandwoodworking.com/msds/MYLANDS%20CELLULOSE%20SANDING%20SEALER.pdf
http://msdsdigital.com/deft-lacquer-sanding-sealer-msds
Mylands Cellulose Sanding Sealer contains a relatively large amount of butyl acetate.

title: Raspberry Pi 3 STEP file remix, stripped down to connectors

description.text:
I needed a model of a Rpi3 for a project and alexandre_willame was kind enough to have put one up. It's a really great STEP and very accurate, but had too much shit on it. So, I deleted everything not relevant to making a case for it and this is that STEP file.
The only things it has are the board, SOC, overhanging connectors and the GPIO pins. It's mainly centered around being easy on the software as Fusion has recently taken a turn for the worse.

Update: Made a second version. It's ugly AF but it has even less bodies to import due to a combine operation.

title: Snap-On Anycubic Kossel Effector Led Strip Bracket

description.text:
Hi,

being new to 3D printing, i felt the need of some light to check what the printer was doing, specially in the first layers. I had some led strip laying around, so i did the brackets to mount directly on the effector.
The rings on the side helps to keep the wiring in place.

The led strip is 8mm wide, and self-adhesive back.
To fit right, there is one for each side (left, right and back) of the effector.

Just print and snap it on the effector.

Feel free to comment and give suggestions about the design, etc.

Printer:

Anycubic Kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

30%

The leds are connected directly to the 12v socket, so the are always on, as you power up the printer.
The next step is to connect them to one pin on the board and drive them via gcode. :-)

Designed in Fusion360
Printed in PLA

description.text:
This handle replaces the knee control of the Segway Mini-Pro. I live in a rural environment with gravel and dirt roads, and need more control than the knee bar offers. I rode the original Segway, and liked it's handle bar control system. I believe the Mini-Pro has a more delicate control arm construction and this new control bar was constructed to not over stress the original control mechanism.
This arm achieves 4 objectives:
Better control than the original.
Balances like the original.
Built in stand.
Built in MiniPro carry handle.
It is also lighter, locks in place and is as easy to remove.
Non-printing materials needed are 3' of 1/2" aluminum rod and 7" of 3/8" aluminum rod or similar.

The top knob is small, meant for gripping with 2 fingers. It doesn't need much side to side force to steer. Forward and reverse are handled by balance as before. I think the paddle handle works best.

The plastic fitting needs to be strong, so it is printed with no fill except for 30% on the bottom plate. The rest is 6 top, 6 bottom and 6 perimeter layers. I printed in ABS, then brushed it with acetone, then 2 hours in an acetone fume chamber to fully bond the layers and produce a glossy finish. There are 2 drain holes in the inside, fill up between the inner and outer wall, then drain. It will cure overnite.

The lock is made with a bit of 1/8" thick or less flat bar bent 90 degrees, drilled and secured with a flat head 3mm bolt screwed from the inside, thru the lock, thru a small spring, secured with a nut and washer. See photo.

Print a 1" test section to check for fit on the MiniPro. I printed at 90% extrusion rate, 2400 feet per minute, sitting on the bottom plate. Cooling was 10% fan after the bottom plate.

The aluminum rods can be threaded or glued. I threaded mine, 1/2-13. The 7" rod is for the handle / stand. The control bar hole will need to be altered or drilled to 1/2" if glued.

The little Tee handle is for the original control bar, as mine broke on first use and I needed something stronger. It is not needed otherwise.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Medium .5mm nozzle .2mm layers

Infill:

Only base, 30%

title: HDMI+DVI+VGA LCD Controller/Driver/Inverter board, mock up, STEP file

description.text:
This is an accurate mock up STEP I just made for use in modeling a case. I figured someone might use it for something, so here it is. Also, nice to have a repo for items like this.
The item goes by the name HDMI+DVI+VGA LCD Controller Board For LP156WH2-TLE1 LP156WH2 TL E1 on eBay. I'm using it with a 15.6" LCD screen I got from a salvaged laptop. Always nice to be able to upcycle those things.

Doing more research, MS489LC LCD Controller seems to be the official name as it's sold on lcdparts.com for 110.

Holes, board connectors and ICs are in the right spots, but the pin connectors are not modeled here as I don't need them for reference.
I didn't take the time to model out the pins and what not, but the main board thickness in the model takes FR4 and pin depth into account.

If it looks really rough, that's because it is. I didn't spend a whole lot of time on it, but if you use it as a subtraction, the jack holes will be good.

If there are any issues, let me know.

title: fast to print flyer dispenser (paper stand)

description.text:
This is a fast-printing flyer holder (or... paper stand ? Honestly idk the official english name).
It's made to hold 20 to 30 A4 pages (folded in 3 obv.). There is a bit of lateral tolerance so it's easy to slip papers in or out.

EDIT : obviously tilt it upward so the base is on your printer bed, didn't saw the STL was tilted...

My significant other wanted a paper holder ASAP for a convention, I searched thingiverse but I only found 6 to 11h prints, so I decided to make one. I thought about how fast "vase mode" was, so I tried to emulate that by making the walls 0.4mm wide (the size of my printer's nozzle, a very common size). Lo and behold, this one print in about 1hour 45 minutes (some slicers make it 3h because past the cutout the nozzle can't simply make circles it has to go back and forth, but you can tweak this).
Included are the .stl and the solidworks files.

Printer:

DiscoEasy200

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

0.15 mm

Doesn't matter

You must have to have a 0.4mm nozzle to fast print this. Smaller and it will take more time, larger and you'll have to tweak your slicer.

title: Nintendo NES - Raspberry Pi 3 Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is yet another Nintendo NES Raspberry Pi Case.

I know there already are some other cool models here on thingiverse, but i wanted to create my own version.

I have used the original dimensions of the NES and scaled them to 1:2. I have tried to match the original design as close as possible.

The case is designed for the Raspberry Pi 3, but i think the Raspberry Pi 2 Model B should also fit (i did not test this !).

I have one to please you:

  • if you like this model: please click the like this thing button
  • if you have some questions or suggestions, please leave a comment
  • if you have printed this model: please share some pictures in i made one
  • if you want to support me you can do the things above and/or use the Tip Designer button ;)

Modular design

There are some extensions planned for the future. That's why i have made some parts interchangeable:

  • The first planned extension is a bottom front cover with slots for 2 USB ports.
  • The next extension will be a buttons cover with real push buttons and a status LED.
  • I have some vague ideas about an insert for a fan.
  • I am waiting for your comments for more cool ideas...

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20% Honeycomb

Notes:

Most parts need support.

I recommend using 4 perimeters, 4 bottom layers and 5 top layers.

The top parts have to be printed upside down. The STL files already come in the right orientation.

description.text:
UPDATE 2018-01-21: Added Hull_Complete files for those who want to adjust to their printer's Z height
Added hatch cover cutting templates

UPDATE 2017-12-05: Added _RevA keel molds: All parts 200 mm long now ;)

UPDATE 2017-11-16: Added readme.

UPDATE 2017-11-11: Added swingrig cross. Sorry, forgot about that one ;)

UPDATE 2017-11-05: All RevB files: Reduced width of foredeck openings so that patches are easier to apply.

UPDATE 2017-11-01: Added m17_Mastbox_universal and m17_midship_universal. This will allow to fit other keel fins than the one from the m17 mold. The universal mastbox will still fit the "normal" midship, but it needs to be aligned for verticality then. See picture for dimensions.

Andreas Hoffmann's manta2017 RG65 design, same design as Euro Open 2017 winner Huub Gillisen sailed. See http://rg-andy.blogspot.com/p/andydesign.html
Ready to sail approx. 900 g with DF65 bulb.
To be printed as single layer spiral vase hull in 0.55 mm wall thickness. Three section hull, stern and midship approx. 200 mm high, bow 253 mm.
NOTE: 4 section version for 200 mm Z height printers added.
UPDATED all _RevA parts: Corrected position of eyes for DF rig (was off by 9 mm).
A 70 mm cardboard tube cap fits the hatch ring.
Front mast position for swingrig, rear for conventional/DF65 rig. Use iglidur JSM 0608-043 for upper bearing and JSM 0405-04 for lower bearing.
Report in German RG65 forum: http://www.forum.rg-65.de/viewtopic.php?f=24&t=2071

Printer:

Anycubic Kossel Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%, all except hull

Notes:

Only Mastbox needs supports.
I print in PLA at 240°C with a 0.3 mm nozzle for best layer adhesion. Hull thickness 0.55 mm. Good part cooling is needed.
Last picture: This is the level of layer adhesion that you're looking for. If your print breaks when doing this, try to improve layer adhesion.
If hull segments don't fit together after deburring (!) or have play, try different hotbed temperature. I am using 55°C nowadays, depends a lot on the PLA brand.
Chamfer aft end of midship and bow 45° for perfect fit. Glue PLA with special CA for PE plastics (set with primer pen and CA glue, expensive but works).
Even better: Solvent glue for acrylglass, based on dichlormethylene.

Recommended gear: Hyperion DH13 FMB as sail servo, DS11 as rudder servo. 2S 850 LiFe battery (48 g) needs to be far forward if DF bulb is used.
Keel Layup per side: 2 layers Carboweave 40 +-45°, 2 layers 25 mm wide 100 g/m² UD carbon, 1 layer Carboweave 40 +-45°, 12k roving in leading edge. Microballoons as shear web and in corners and trailing edge. Close mold while wet.

comments.text:
Hi Philipp
Thanks for posting this project. I, too, have been printing RC yachts for some years, limiting myself to fittings, rudders, RG65 and the new NANO class. Another of our club members has also been printing hulls, including these and the IOM class. We are slowly convincing others of the benefits of 3D printing as evidenced by the introduction of the new Nano class which is solely for 3D printing. You might be interested in my Nano design on Thingiverse (under NANO). On the subject of suitable glues, the only one that seems to work OK on PLA is epoxy on an abraded surface. Also, best to print with a light coloured PLA as the hull will distort if you leave it in the sun for too long as I discovered!!!
Regards
Brian
comments.author: ebdill

comments.text:
Hi Brian,
thanks a lot for your comment, great to hear from you! I didn't notice you and S. were in the same club. Of course I noticed your Nano, but have to admit that I didn't try it yet, I was already too far into the Manta at that moment. I really hope our boats will encourage others to share their designs as well! there must be some more out there ;)
I have to say though that I can't recommend epoxy for my particular manta2017 files, as the mating surfaces are too small. I was always able to peel off epoxy bonds, no matter how I prepared the surface. Epoxy only seems to create a mechanical bond to the roughened surface, but it doesn't adhere to the material itself. Therefore, for this manta2017, I recommend to use special CA with primer for PE plastics, or, MUCH better, solvent glue based on dichlormethylene (Akurisande- アクリサンデー in Japan).
And about the PLA in the sun, been there, done that ;) the printer came with black PLA, and when I took some parts to the pond to show off, guess what happened...
Happy holidays and happy printing!
Philipp
comments.author: ebdill

comments.text:
Hi Philipp
I discovered PATTEX super glue with an activator yesterday by accident in one of my local department stores, tried it, and it seems to work really well. I have printed most of your Manta 17 files and will join everything up shortly. It will be interesting to compare performance with my designs. I currently have a couple of RG65s in various stages of completion, but am going to complete yours first so I can compare it with my carbon home design which is very competitive in my club. S's boats are also doing very well and we provide good competition for each other. Have you checked out his website? Do your files give a position for conventional lower rigs, or do you use all swing rigs? I have been using swing rigs since the early '90s, mostly in Marbleheads. Yes, black and dark grey don't like the sun! I am happy to share any information with you.
Regards
Brian
comments.author: GER776

comments.text:
Hi Brian,
excellent news that you were able to find the Pattex glue - is it called PLASTIX? Then it might be the same stuff that I used in Germany. Interesting - Pattex seems to be much more international than I thought!
I have used a conventional rig only on the first prototype, simply because I had the DragonForce rig available. Soon I built a swing rig, and found it to be so fast and so much fun that I never looked back... The aft mast position is for the conventional rig, balance with the DF rig was spot on. I just noticed there are some updates on S's homepage. Interesting stuff, say hello from me! Probably not needed given your experience - you're doing swing rigs since more than 20 years, I built my first one five months ago!
Regards, Philipp

comments.text:
Hi,
Nice 3D-Design of the RG65 Manta!
While printing i came across a few issues:
I loaded the files for the keel mold into slic3er, but i saw that the halfs have different hights: 195 & 205mm. Is that on purpose?
My printer has a limited hight of 200mm, so that the solution for me is cutting off 5mm from the upper mold parts.
Maybe you can add the 200 & 200 mm version thinking of us other guys with limited printer hight ;-) ?
Another suggested improvement is to make the mastbox printable without support: The keel & mast box needs a lot of support material. (Around 25g support vs 15g netto weight in my case)
Putting on 45° slope up the vertical part starting from the lower flat horizontal planes edge and turning it around while printing would make it printable without extra support, while keeping the extra weight as low as possible under the sealine. Maybe i will give that improvement a try with my limited 3D modeling skills...
Thanks a lot for this upload!
Br Georg

description.text:
Z spacer to account for the offset between nozzles with duplication mode on a BCN3D Sigma.
Exported at 1 mm height - just scale it on Z to account for your offset, print solid.

To get the offset run a full calibration (unless you have just recently) and execute M503 to read the offsets afterwards.
M530 has the Z offset for the left nozzle to print the spacer with.
Up to .1 mm is easier compensated with slightly fastening the nuts and does not require a spacer.

See BCN3D's wiki on Github for instructions on the duplication modes available and how to set up each.

Es un camión con a partic del robot DYOR, las funciones de este robot son:

  • Control remoto desde el móvil con una aplicaión para este proposito.
  • Detector de escalones con una sensor de luz en la base.
  • Detector de obstaculos con unos sensores de ultrasonidos.
  • Sonidos.
  • Pantalla de leds de 8x8 con diferentes figuras.
  • Volquete de la caja con un servo.
    Las ruedas delanteras no deben de tocar en el suelo para que pueda hacer bien los giros, son solo decorativas y para mejorar la estabilidad del juguete, hay que dejarlas que puedan rodar por si en algun caso tocan con alguna alfombra o algo que no lo frenen.

Los materiales necesarios para este son los siguientes:
1 Arduino Nano v3.0 y placa de expansión I/O Arduino Nano
1 batería USB (powerbank)
2 micro servos de rotación continua FS90R y ruedas de 60mm
1 micro servo SG90
1 sensor de ultrasonidos (SR-HC04)
1 módulo seguilineas TCRT5000
1 matriz de LEDs 8x8 (max7219)
1 zumbador pasivo (KY-006)
1 módulo bluetooth (HC-06)
1 rueda loca
1 cable USB
1 móvil o tablet Android
22 tornillos de 3x15
Las piezas realizadas con impresión 3d
Se adjunta el programa para la placa arduino así "DYOR_CAMION.bly" como la aplicación para Android "DYOR_CAMION.apk"
Las entradas de la bateria hay que ponerlas a la parte trasera para facilitar la conexion y desconexión de los cables, se necesita una cables mas manejable que el que viene en el kit para que no interfiera con e volquete cuando se levanta.

Printer:

BQ Hephestos Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

La cabina hay que imprimirla con el techo en el cristal y con soporte solo en la base.
El resto de piezas son soporte
La base recomiento la impresión con relleno al 100% .
Con las piezas del robot DYOR he construido este camión.

Para más información: Curso MOOC EdX: https://www.edx.org/course/disena-fabrica-y-programa-tu-propio-upvalenciax-dyor101x Portal de formación robot DYOR: http://dyor.roboticafacil.es Blog robótica de la UPV: http://robotica.webs.upv.es Twitter (@roboticaUPV): https://twitter.com/roboticaUPV Facebook (robótica UPV): https://www.facebook.com/roboticaUPV

remixed_from.title: Complete Biker Scout armor Star Wars

description.text:
A remodel of the mouth piece to fit sn3850's Scout Trooper helmet. Is it screen accurate, hell no but it does (imo) look better than the original mouth piece that goes with his model. I've not put my helmet together yet but a test fit on the pieces it looks like it will go on nicely.

Thanks sn3850 for the original model andthanks to SteveZZR for the remix I printed.

Update:
Added v3 to make the fins look a bit better. This gives them a flat top instead of rounded, should look a bit smoother when printed. I'll update pics once I reprint.

Update:
Added a more accurate version (v5). It's still far from 501st approved but better than previous attempts. Also included a version with just the body and just the mic in case you want to paint the mic separately and glue it on (it looks a bit tricky to paint otherwise).

Update: painted the original and printed (in the wrong size) the new one. Also added a mesh for the mic that I repurposed from a shore trooper costume I'm about to start (shoretrooper.co.uk).

Update:
I'm finished on this model. It's good enough for me. It could do with better sizing. I actually printed the body scaled up to 108% and sanded back the 4mm that poked out the bottom. I suggest just printing the x at 108% and don't use uniform scaling. The cylinder and mesh I printed at 100% size.

See this for moulding the eye pieces:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2595527

title: 1-Axis Pen Holder w. Bronze Bushings
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I like the original design but did not have any leftover 8mm rod.
So i redesigned the parts to fit the 10mm aluminium tubing and the bronze bushings since so many were left over after building the hypercube. Also i "touched" up the design a bit since i am a fan of smooth edges.

Thanks Tech2C for the great designs and the hard work you are putting in this project!

Printer:

Hypercube

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15

Notes:

Print flat side down.

2x 10x53mm Aluminium Tubing
2x Bronze Bushing
1x M3x20mm Button Head Screw ISO7380
4x M3 Hex nut
1x M3 self-locking Hex nut

nx Rubber rings (n... number depending on pressure of tip you want to achieve)

OPTIONAL
The 10mm aluminium tubing was a tight fit on my design but i have included 4 addional holes where M3 screws should fit to secure the rods better if they are loose.

1. Install the 2 bronze bushings in the 3d printed clamp.
2. Install the 4 M3 hex nuts in the main body. If the hex hole is too tight, you can try to use a screw to force the nut in.
3. Install the clamp on the main body by pushing the aluminium tubes through the clamp that is already lying atop the body.
4. Fix the self-locking hex nut in the Screwgrip and screw it tight with a M3x20 screw.
5. Install the last M3 hex nut in the grip that holds the pen and use the prepared screw grip assembly to pull the hex nut in the hex hole.
6. Affix the rubber band to the main body and clamp
7. Install on printer for use

DONE

title: Cargador Xiaomi Mi6: de chino a europeo

description.text:
03/01/2018. Añadido archivo de solidworks por si alguien quiere modificar las medidas y adaptarlo a otros cargadores de xiaomi. Advierto que soy usuario novato en solidworks y seguramente no está hecho de la forma más ortodoxa. ;-)

08/10/2017. Nueva versión V2. He puesto la unión entre las piezas 2 y 3 en la parte central del cargador lo que da más consistencia a esa parte y además permite imprimir la pieza 3 sin usar soportes (ya no se utilizan para ninguna pieza). También hay algunas pequeñas modificaciones de tipo estético. La pieza 1 sigue siendo la misma que antes.

07/10/2017. Cuando compras un teléfono Xiaomi en China (en este caso un Mi6 de Gearbest) a veces su cargador viene con la clavija china y no la europea. Si es así, en el paquete también viene un adaptador. Con esto ya se puede poner el teléfono a cargar, pero es fácil que el cargador se salga del adaptador, no hacen una unión muy sólida. Para arreglar esto he hecho este diseño, con lo que ahora la unión es totalmente sólida.
Las medidas del cargador y del adaptaor son las que están en las imágenes.

title: V3 Printer bracket for Ikea LEDBERG LED strip.

description.text:
I wanted more light so I could keep an eye on the print when it was getting darker so I bought a pack of Ikea LEDBERG led strips. The pack comes with 3 strips with a 24 volt plug in power supply. Because the V3 uses a 24 volt PSU I wired the strip directly to the internal PSU. This requires soldering wires onto the strip connectors. BE CAREFULL not to short them together if you choose to do the same. I am NOT responsible for how you decide to power the LED strip(s).

I have just the one strip attached at the moment but intend to fit another to the right side (looking from the front of the printer) pretty soon. The bracket can be fitted on either side of the printer. It uses the two middle side screws that attach the left or right column covers to the frame. The original screws are long enough so no new screws required.

The original brackets relied on double sided sticky pads (mirror tabs) to hold the strip in place but on my printer, when printing ABS the heat caused the pads to unstick. V2 od the design had clips top and bottom to hold the strip but weren't wide enough. V3 is this one and holds the strip in place nicely.

I made the brackets big enough to hold the LED strips with double sided pads also attached but do work without pads.

title: Foco para bombillla led 12 voltios, con bateria de moto/coche o fuente alimentación 12 v. (Focus for 12 volt led bulb, with motorcycle / car battery or power supply 12 v.)

description.text:
Foco para lampara de led. Este consta de 4 piezas: el portalamparas en sí, el foco, la parte de cierre con una parte del mecanismo de giro y la parte posterior, que he diseñado dos piezas. La primera que diseñe para ponerle 9 imanes de neodimio pequeños, pero, al tener mucho peso y la dificultad de pegar con pegamento epoxi dichos imanes no logran que el foco se quede adherido a una superficie metálica. La pieza denominada "engranaje con imán gordo" tiene una cavidad para ponerle un imán de neodimio, el cual hace que el foco se adhiera a cualquier metal y es difícil de despegar. Este imán lo adquirir en Amazon por unos 17 €. El foco y el portalámpara hay que limarlos un poco para que encajen y los tornillos deben de ser pequeños. La pieza denominada "con9imanes" la atornillaré a la pared y haré otro foco. Para que los engranajes hagan el giro ponerle un tornillo pasante con una arandela y una tuerca (tipo tuerca palometa es más fácil), esta ultima no hace falta apretar mucho, simplemente hasta que encajen los dientes del engranaje. Todavía no lo he hecho pero quiero pintar la parte interior del foco con purpurina, hay vídeos que dejan la superficie imponente para reflejar la luz. También se puede construir el foco con material tipo plata o dorado.
Traduccion Google:
Focus for led lamp. This consists of 4 pieces: the lamp holder itself, the bulb, the closing part with a part of the turning mechanism and the back, I have designed two pieces. The first to design 9 small neodymium magnets, but having a lot of weight and the difficulty of gluing with epoxy glue said magnets do not achieve that the focus is attached to a metal surface. The piece called "engranaje con iman gordo" has a cavity to put a neodymium magnet, which makes the bulb stick to any metal and is difficult to take off. This magnet is purchased on Amazon for about 17 €. The bulb and bulb holder have to be lined up a bit to fit and the screws must be small. The piece called "con9imanes" will screw it to the wall and make another focus. To make the gears turn by turning a through screw with a washer and a nut (nut type is easier), the latter does not need to tighten much, simply until the gear teeth fit. I have not done it yet but I want to paint the inner part of the spotlight with glitter, there are videos that leave the imposing surface to reflect the light. You can also build the bulb with silver or gold type material.

In order to automate my dust extraction system, I designed automated blast gates based on standard metal blast gates and R/C servos.

The servo mount attaches to the existing screw holes of the frame. Simply replace the existing screws by longer M4 20mm ones. The carriage mount is fixed to the lip of the carriage by a friction fit. The small arm is fixed to the grooved servo shaft via form and friction fit, as it is slightly undersized and the grooves of the metal shaft press into the plastic. As my servo shaft has an internal thread, I additonally secured the small arm via the small screw, which is normally used to mount the crossed horn onto the shaft. In terms of the servo, I used a standard sized version (no mini or micro!), as it provides sufficient torque to move the carriage. Check via the picture above, if your servo fits into the cutout. I provided two versions of the servo mount, so you can choose on which side of the blast gate you would like to mount it.

Why the rubber band?
A negative side effect caused by mounting position of the servo is a transverse force, which pushes the carriage sidewards against the frame and thereby causes friction and occasional blockings. I applied some grease to the edges of the carriage, which helped a lot. Beyond that I added a simple rubber band to generate a counterforce and prevents blockings. I mounted the rubber band three months ago and until now could not observe any wear out. However, in the long term it might be more benefitial to replace it by a proper metal spring. If you have other ideas, let me know!

4"/100mm Blast Gate / Absperrschieber:
https://www.holz-metall.info/shop1/artikel8019.htm#tech

Servo (Its torque of 35Ncm is a little on the weak side, get stronger ones if you can!)
https://www.conrad.de/de/modelcraft-standard-servo-rs2-mgbb-analog-servo-getriebe-material-metall-stecksystem-jr-205111.html

Update 30/01/2018
I added an alternative servo connector, which fits onto a traditional servo cross. I experienced that the orignal servo connector printed in PLA could not handle the torque transfered by the servo gear and wore out.

title: Broken hoover head joint fix for Grundig Cyclonic 21.6V

description.text:
Apparently the design of the rotating joint for the Grundig Cyclonic 21.6V hoover head, is so flimsy that it cannot handle normal usage...

Luckily, the rest of the parts for the joint have a spacious and open build, which means that the need for designing a complicated replacement part is not needed.

I've designed two small components that can be pushed in the rotating grove and will lock into place on their own, and be hold into place by having a slight modification to the top bracket on the joint.

  1. Print the parts.
  2. Remove the hoover head from the hoover.
  3. Remove the 2 only screws on the head in order to remove the top bracket.
  4. Push in the printed parts then the grove.
  5. Modify the top bracket by cutting of the inner support walls that otherwise will be in the way of the printed parts (the walls are not needed for structural integrity, so the hoover won't be diminished by this).
  6. Fit the top bracket back on and the head on the hoover.

This fix is really version 2. As you can see on the pictures duck tape was applied before and barely kept it together - Now I have the problem of removing the residue. Wish I did not use that damn tape... Oh well, at least it works again.

description.text:
Here's a simple milk frother.
I designed this because my old one has broken and I have a 3D-printer... ;-)

I used old parts. Switch and motor from electronics-scrap. The essay from a broken milk frother. The power supply is from my old WIFI-Access-Point.

Materials:

  • Motor with diameter of 24mm and length of 30mm (RF-280 or similar)
  • Switch (snap-in with dimensions of 19,2x12,9mm)
  • Power supply with 5V or 6V and at least 500mA current (5V is easier to handle and 6V has more power; If you are unsure, I recommend the 5Volts)

After printing I have reworked the 4 holes with a 4mm drill.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Part1 I printed with support.
Part2 doesn't need support.

author: DataMouse

description.text: cupboard next door

I modelled this on Ubermeister's Beer Bottle Stein Holder, which I printed early January, The one and only problem I had with it was the very thin neck support holding the bottle. I found that when printing, the neck tended to miss align so that the material didn't adhere very well and was quite weak. I remodelled this with Inventor 2014, after several trials came up with a quite solid and strong print. Get your BBQ's ready for summer and start printing. Finally figured that Autodesk Inventor was exporting the STL file in CM not MM so it's 10x smaller than it should be.
New Version added with more clearance between handle and bottle for those with chunky fingers.
Please add comments if you have made one to let me know what you think, thanks ScottyLad

The handle prints in 2 parts, I am using a Makerbot Replicator 2X with 110° plate and 235° extruder temp. I have also tried to make the joints stronger by using 3 wall thickness's although it does print well with 2 and 15% fill. Hi Scotty, Sorry new to this and not sure how/why it imports it so small, I did model it in MM and tend to find that if I scale it to 1015% it prints full size and allows for shrinkage. (Inventor exported in cm not mm, corrected with L-Handle version) Also if you print the text 6mm from the bed it should be the right
height. Hope it turns out ok. Large Handle version Added (L-Handle) Std Text.stl can also be used with this model.

comments.text: Hi Scottylad, wow I bet that looks great, the model with the larger handle are the files with L- as in L-handle. There is just a slightly larger gap between the handle and bottle. It needs to be printed with the new base and top due to the remodelled shape. Let me know how you go on........Cheers.

description.text:
This is a reasonably large fidget spinner. It's not easy to spin with one hand but with good weights it spins well using two. I've made a smaller MkII version as well (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2573142).

I've used skate board bearing sized holes (608) both for the actual bearing and for the weights. As I don't like wasting bearings as weights I've used different "adapters" for each of these two prints - the bearing2hexnut adapter (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2044157) and my own bearing2marble adapter (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2573118) for the marble version.

The steampunky design fits well with either hex nuts or marbles (though I prefer the marbles aesthetically myself). For the marble version I've gold sprayed the spinner and used a miniature wash to get the patina look, then sprayed it with a varnish to let it keep the colour even after weeks of spinning.

Hello reader,

This is a remix of the Prusa Mk2s fan nozzle in order to add LED light to the printer. It helps a lot to check how's the printing process going. I used a LED ring (12V) of 70 mm diameter. It fitted perfectly. You may find here the reference: https://www.amazon.fr/gp/product/B074GNZ9KL/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
The wires are connected directly to the transformer passing through the box with the electronic board. On Prusa's transformer a third port of 12v is available. You may add a light switch on the wires knowing that during the calibration of the first layer the light should be turned off as its heat may influence the reading of the height calibration senzor.

Happy printing to all!

This is the STL files for a:
Cubietruck Cubieboard3 Cortex-A7 Dual-Core 2GB RAM/8GB Flash with Wifi + BT and 2.5" SATA hard-drive This model works best when you use bottom standoffs on one layer of the plexiglass sheets that they send with the board. Put this plexiglass layer underneath the board and the bottom stand-offs fit into the holes. Your 2.5" SATA drive will fit underneath the plexiglass with room for the cables to go up one side. Note: shorter standoffs into cubietruck board -> plexiglass sheet -> longer standoffs -> holes in base plate (Sata drive under plexiglass)

Used calipers and multiple passes to get all the ports correctly sized and a nice tight fit to hold both the board and the disk drive securely.  
When printing turn on "Raft" so you can remove it and also not have it pop off the build plate on a corner.  The lid in the picture was printed at low-res,  I have done variants of it with slots for cooling

description.text:
This adapter is meant to let you replace bearing weights in, for instance, your spinner with marbles (as I happened to have a whole load of those lying around the house). It's made to fit marbles and ball bearings from about 14,5 mm up to 16 mm (though 16 might be a pretty tight squeeze and anything less than 14.5 would fall out).

This should work well with most standard toy marbles, even though they come in pretty irregular sizes and finishes at this scale.

Please note that in order for the marble to fit the adapter shouldn't form a complete circle. See the note under print settings.

description.text:
I created this to help me spray paint my prints more easily. The holder works as a hook for items to dry, as a pincer to pick newly sprayed items up (to let them dry) and as a way to easily and relatively risk free transport newly spray painted items.

This has proven particularly useful when I've varnished items as the transparency of the varnish has allowed me to use the hook in places that would be unsuitable for an opaque paint.

I've combined the holder with a standard plastic tube from a miniature paint brush that I sometimes use as a lock (as illustrated in the photo).

The holder flexes well and can be attached in multiple ways thanks to it's shape and the three holes in its frame.

(In the photo the holder is holding the frame of a fidget spinner that hasn't yet been painted.)

title: Mini / Micro Skyhunter Wing Platform Camera Mount

description.text:
This is a mount I designed for the ReadyMadeRC Mini Skyhunter, also known as the Eachine Micro Skyhunter, Sonicmodel Mini Skyhunter, etc. This is for the mid-sized version, not the full Skyhunter nor the Nano.

This mount is to be used above the wing, utilizing the screw that hold the wing in place. It has two places to mount a camera via tripod screw, and a center area where you can attach something via a strap. It weighs a little under 40g, and lets you mount your gear close to the CoG.

I designed the mount to carry a 360 degree camera in the center position, or a GoPro (using the official tripod mount) in the front hole position. You can use it to mount just about anything though, and it is easily removed when needed.

The mount in the first photo was my first version with only a single hole and lacking several other improvements. The STL version is strong, lighter, and has the second hole and strap mount area.

I printed in Raptor PLA, but the annealment process caused too much shrinking, so I skipped it in later versions. You can print in PETG for extra strength, but honestly the mount is pretty strong as-is and if you crash hard enough to break the mount on the wing you've got worse problems :)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GVsZuuxBmCU

Print upside-down with the legs pointing upwards. Supports may be needed for the screw holes, depending on your printer.

Non-Slip Coating

After you print, spread a semi-thick coat of "Amazing Goop" craft glue evenly on the top and let dry. This will make a great non-slip surface that will help keep your gear in place!

description.text:
This bottle-cutter is used to cut a straight groove in a Bottle.
It fits a Silberschnitt glas-cutter wich works great for cutting all kinds of Glas.
After you put the groove on the bottle you can easily apply heat and cold to make the bottle crack along the line.

The M8 Thread for the Thumbscrew has been made with a tap for better screwability.
With the long M5 screws it is adjustable to fit a lot of bottle-sizes.

Bottlecutter.stl needs to be printed two times and you'll need 32 pieces of BC_Wheel.stl.

You'll need the following additional hardware:

8x Screws M8 x 40(you can get longer if you like)
8x Nuts M8
1x Thumbscrew M8
2x Screws M5 x 80
1x Silberschnitt 15024 glas-cutter/Glasschneider (http://amzn.to/2yOMu8a)
1x M8 Tap

print_settings.Notes:: If you make this model and have other helpful tips please add them to the comments.

title: Lunar Patrol -  6 Wheel Rover
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This Lunar Patrol rover is inspired by the Irem / Williams video game Moon Patrol. This video game from 1982 is credited with introducing and popularizing "parallax side scrolling" as a graphics feature. Also, I remember this being one of the first games that allowed you to "continue" by adding more coins / tokens.

I styled this model from an Atari advertisement from 1983 which had a great retro 60's sci-fi feel to it. Angular and simplified, it resembles the original video game image pretty closely. The only thing that I styled to be a bit more modern are the hub-less wheels. This allowed for a bit more ground clearance, and a simplified way to connect the flexible suspension arms. Plus its pretty neat to show off what 3D printing can do with captive rings.

This model is printed in multiple parts, and will require the use of a flexible filament for the tires and suspension arms. I have used Sainsmart TPU and MakerGeeks Flex both without issue for these components.

The hub-less wheels have a print tolerance built in of 0.3mm. This prints easily on my Prusa I3 MK2s. However I do recommend you test print one wheel first before printing the entire model. I don't recommend scaling down unless your print tolerance is very good. Again, test any scaling by printing the wheel first.

I have included two body styles. The standard "body top" prints without supports and no additional parts. The second body, allows the use of separate printable windows and headlights that can be glued in. The fit tolerance on these parts in 0.1mm for a tight friction fit. Glue is recommended for assembly of the rear window, and two side windows. Glue will be required for the headlights. Both guns and front window friction fit in pretty tight, so glue is not needed for a static model.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20 layer height

Infill:

25% for most parts

Notes:

When printing the TPU suspension arms, I made sure to use 3 shells and 25% infill. You can adjust this as you see fit for a stiffer suspension. However I felt this was pretty good for some give and even with a scaled up version that my son plays with its pretty durable yet flexible. Your experience with different filament or printers could affect this so you may want to print one and see how it works for you first before printing all 6.

All other parts can be printed as you best see fit. However you will need to print the "window body" with supports, this is mainly for the front window overhang. If you have the ability to add manual supports this is the only place you will need it. The front "gun" mount prints fine without supports.

I have printed this model with both PETG and PLA and it works great with both. I have not tested with ABS, but assume if you are experienced with ABS, it will be fine.

If you make this model and have other helpful tips please add them to the comments.

Tips:

Glue: I recommend using CA glue ( super glue ) for any parts you wish to permanently connect. Depending on your printer, you may not need any glue at all for final assembly. However please note that some parts are small and with all toys, there is a potential choking hazard.

Hub-less Wheel Lubrication: You might find that the hub-less wheels could use some lubrication. Silicone spray lubricant works great, however look for one that is safe for plastic. I have tried WD40's version and that works well. The CRC brand I also have states it is not safe for plastic. While it does work, it puts a permanent haze on some PLA's. Again I recommend testing on waste or scrap material before proceeding.

author: Frankie4

description.text:
Riding an electric unicycle is cool. But riding a cloud is even cooler!

This is a cover for a Ninebot One E+, that hides the unicycle and makes you appear standing on a cloud. This particular cloud design happens to be the cloud from the ownCloud logo. Done for showing sponsorship at dvocc17.

The cover was cut from 10mm sheets of white PU foam. The biggest part is the center circle of 45cm diameter. All the other parts fit into a smallish 300mm x 400mm lasercutter.
The assembled cloud stands 65cm high and is 118cm long.

Please refer to the included STL file to see how the individual parts are layered. I've glued them ontop of each other with lots of hot glue. Not the perfect method, as foam keeps the heat in much longer than one would expect. So the parts do not immediatly stick, and pressing the glued areas caused multiple blisters on my fingers. Ouch!

The included SVG file contains multiple layers. That helps you to follow the construction steps from photo to a layout ready for lasercutting.

To produce the full cover, you need to cut all parts twice. Assemble one cloud as shown in the STL, the other as a mirror image. Finally glue them togeather leaving the bottom open, and also one or two openings at the top, so that you can reach inside to grab the handle and find the power button.
Housing and bracket for 28BYJ-48 5V DC Stepper motor to be used to add to robot frame.
Small spatula that I use for spot putty after priming my 3D-printed model trains. Very useful when working on small areas.

title: Spring airsoft grenade, by Myrmecoman
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Discover the very first 3D printable spring airsoft grenade !
When I saw this 80 euros spring grenade for sale on the web I told myself « this is just plastic and spring, it must be printable for 10 euros ! ». So I went to work and here’s the result.

The system is pretty simple but works great ! It consists in a spring chamber and a BB chamber. When you put down the BB chamber, you compress the spring and lock the system with the arm. Put the safetey pin and your grenade is safe. It will explode with a choc, you can adjust the sensibility of the system with the screw that keeps it compressed.
Note that you will have to file the feeding hole for the BBs to fit perfectly in.

What you’ll need to mount your grenade :

  • 1 classic AEG spring (not much than 450fps !)
  • 4 drill screws of 4mm from 25 to 40 mm long
  • 1 drill screw of 4mm from 50 to 80mm long
  • 1 screw of 5mm with it’s nut
  • 1 safety pin of 2mm

See the video for the mounting tutorial. ;)
Also see the sensibility of the grenade and the spreading test in the video !

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZBRupehvX2Q&feature=youtu.be

Make sur to print the keeper (piece with the 4 holes) with a 100% infill !
Have a good print !

EDIT : added the parts printable separately.
New spreading head for better BB range of dispersion.

Printer:

Discoeasy 200

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2 or 0,15

Infill:

33%

comments.text:
Works pretty good for a simple spring grenade. I have only a little issue with the reloading hole for the BB´s. In my case it is a little bit too low (attached picture). I think it would be better to higher the hole about 5mm.
I also have to shorten the spreading head 4mm to prevent losing BB´s.

description.text:
Model I made in Autodesk Inventor of the Sunder, one of Kagrenac's Tools which has appeared in the Elder Scrolls Morrowind. This item was designed based on game reference images and the seal on the side of the head was based on a design by Mooncactus for The Skywind mod for Skyrim.

Model is completely orginal not ported from the game. Sunder design is by Bethesda. Should be split into small enough pieces for most printers. I have included full files of the head, shaft, and grip as well as files that are cut to fit smaller printers, and I have included a textured and nontextured grip. This is a very large print that comes in around 19" long.

More Elder Scrolls prints coming soon!

description.text:
Adapter to use for Cane Creek 40 crown race, used on my mountain bike tapered fork. I'm not sure which other crown races it will work on.

You will need a crown race setting tool, or if you are DIY, go to homedepot/lowes and buy a 2ft segment of 1.5" PVC, with an end cap that you can hammer onto.

WARNING: I used an online recommendation of using the pipe with a 1.5" coupler straight onto my crown race (with no adapter) and I damaged my gasket that is built onto the crown race because the pipe coupler was slightly too large. So then I had to buy another crown race, and with my adapter it went on so easy.
